title: 113_hr2230
content:
The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes sections on improved climate assessments, service-wide 360 assessments, health welfare inspections, and reviews of security and diversity management. The Act also authorizes appropriations. Congress found an increase in reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces in fiscal year 2012, with a significant rise in anonymous reports. A high percentage of female and male members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced sexual harassment. Retaliation was perceived by many who reported unwanted sexual contact. (4) 62% of members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced social, administrative, or professional retaliation. (5) Commanders must comply with climate assessments to ensure a safe environment. (6) Early identification of harmful behaviors like sexual harassment is crucial. (7) Reasons for not reporting incidents include lack of action and fear of career impact. (8) Commanders condoning sexual misconduct perpetuate the behavior. Commanders condoning or ignoring certain types of sexual misconduct in the military perpetuate the behavior, hindering cultural change. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "sexual harassment" is defined in Department of Defense Directive 1350.2, and "sexual assault" refers to offenses described in section 920 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 4. IMPROVED CLIMATE ASSESSMENTS AND DISSEMINATION AND TRACKING OF RESULTS. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Senior commanders must indicate compliance with assessments in performance evaluations, failure to conduct assessments will impact promotions. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will create a tracking system for assessments. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' conduct of command climate assessments. Unit commanders, in collaboration with the Inspector General, will compile climate assessments and create compliance reports detailing concerns, perceptions of leadership, and plans to address issues. The Secretary of Defense will require commanders to include reprimands, counseling statements, and actions related to sexual harassment or assault in performance evaluations to increase visibility, identify trends of bad behavior early, and prevent the transfer of offenders. Additionally, there will be service-wide 360 assessments implemented. SEC. 6. SERVICE-WIDE 360 ASSESSMENTS.

(a) Each military department must develop a 360-degree assessment program based on the Army's MSAF Program.
(b) The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress within 90 days on the feasibility of including the 360-degree approach in performance evaluations.
(c) Individual counseling is to be included in the performance evaluation process.

SEC. 7. HEALTH WELFARE INSPECTIONS.

Monthly health welfare inspections are required by each military department to maintain security, readiness, order, and discipline. Results will be provided to commanders and senior commanders. SEC. 8. REVIEW OF SECURITY OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS, INCLUDING BARRACKS AND MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCES. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure the safety of Armed Forces members and their dependents. The review will identify security gaps and assess the feasibility of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel at entry points. A report with cost estimates to address security gaps and implement 24-hour monitoring must be submitted to Congress within 90 days. Congress will receive a report with cost estimates to eliminate security gaps and provide 24-hour security monitoring based on a study conducted by the Secretary of Defense on military installations. The Secretary of Defense will review the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity's role in sexual harassment cases, evaluating resource gaps, the office's involvement in such cases, and its collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2014 to support the review.
